div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are Intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid fall fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent, on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: ARE WE LIVING IN A FOOL'S PARADISE ?
div.p: It is gratifying to note, says the Earl of Errol in the "Nineteenth Century," that the speech by Lord Roberts in January last before the members of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce, in which he stated in plain terms that the country was living in a fool's paradise, as well as his exposition of the views of the National Service League, have found some sobo in the Press, even if they have produced little effect on the minds of the publio. It presents a curious illustration of the apathy of our countrymen that so serious an indictment, coming from such an authoritative source, should fail to carry conviction to the minds of all thinking men, and seems to justify the contention of the gravedigger in "Hamlet" that all Englishmen are mad. .. The Japane-e say that we think too much of our rights and too little of our duties, and I think this is a truth which wants continually rubbing into the conscience of the country. Not that we are without patriotism of a kind, but it lies very deep below the surface and wants a deal of waking up... What patriotism we have is no longer the patriotism of our fathers. It is ephemeral and emotional, and bursts forth only in times of great excitement. It waver flags and shouts, and repeats that Britons never shall be slaves, but refrains from taking the 'necessary steps to prevent such a contingency... It cannot be too soft or repeated that the War Office was called upon to send 850,000 men to South Africa during the war, and that the country only provided them with the machinery for sending 80,000. Public opinion was not at that time sufficiently instructed to insist on a state of preparation adequate to our responsibilities. Is it more so now? ... I hold that public opinion on this point (individual responsibility for the efficiency of the fighting forces of the country) should be formed on the reasoned and thoughtful study of the question, and based on the expert opinion of professional advisors, and that every effort should be made to educate sad instruøt the people with view to their insisting on their rulers taking the necessary steps to achieve the end in view. In no other way on War Minister get the necessary backing to enable him to grapple with the question in an adequate and radical manner. ... It is always an advantage "to see ourselves as others see us," even if it does not conduce to our national vanity. The Japanese are a practical people. We are so no longer. They take the necessary precautions and I make the necessary sacrifices that they may be strong in the hope of trial. We trust to luck to pull us through somehow... What if we are living in fool's paradise and if we wake up some morning to find ourselves attacked by a powerful enemy, and hit one, two, three, below the belt before we are ready, and before we have realised that war is upon us! It was thus that the Russians were surprised at Port Anthor, and it is admitted that the whole nation was staggered by the reddanner of the onslaught. It is recorded how the officers were enjoying themselves on shore, some dancing, some taking their recreation in other ways, when the Japanese guns were heard destroying their fleet in the harbour. The attack was so sudden and unexpected, and the disaster so irreparable in ito moral and its material aspects, that its effort was felt till the last day of the war. What guarantee have we that we shall not be found similarly unprepared if attacked in like circumstances, and whose fault will it be! Shall we be found marrying and giving in marriage, attending race meetings, playing football, or rather watching others playing football, and enjoying our undefended and unprotected increment ? Will this increment survive ? Shall we at the end of a great var be in a similar state of prosperity to that. in which we are now, and will our people enjoy the same liberty and prosperity as at present? These are questions which they most decide for themselves. It will be too late to throw the blame on to the War Office, or to plead as an excuse for their onmutual apathy that they were without warning. Military men of the highest authority have spoken in no uncertain tones, magazine articles, speeches in and out of Parliament, letters of soldier and civilians in the daily Press have for months been rubbing in the inadequacy of the military forces of the country. They have appealed to the patriotism of the artizou, they have appealed to his interest, they have held up the bushido of the Japanese and his self-sacrificing love of country. They have piped, but the proletariat has not danced. The people refuse to be persuaded; they prefer to be dooeived by the propbeoy of smooth things, and to present a dead wall of apathy and indifference to the warnings, of an educated and expert opinion. It is this feeling of prajadica that prevents the individual citizen from accepting his share of the responsibility for the defense of his country and the maintenance of the Empire, and which paralyses all attempts on the part of a War Minister to propound any scheme for the proper development of the military foroes of the nation.... .. . .. We don't want an army on the Continental pattern, but we do want a reserve of the best manhood of the country to fall back upon in case of necessity. The question is, how are we to get it, how are we to utilise to the best advantage the fine material we have at hand? At present the proposals pat forward by the National Service League would seem to offer the best solution of the problem, but to carry them out, the individual citizen must be educated to realise the debt which he owes to his Fatherland, and the dangers to which his want of patriotism exposes it.

div.head: Quarantine.
div.p: A medical examination is now imposed on arrivals from Alexandria in Turkish ports.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail.
div.p: The mail for Europe, via Port Said and Brindisi, will close at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 3 10 p.m on Sunday.

div.head: Alhambra
div.p: The variety company performing at the Alhambra is meeting with great success Tonight, Mlle Morlaye, from the Paris Soala, will make her reappearance, and Mlle Suzanne de Lnasao will make her debut.

div.head: Buried Alive.
div.p: A native workman, while digging swell at Zarabana, Ramleh, yesterday afternoon, was overwhelmed by an avalanche of earth and stones. His dead body was afterward extricated from the debris.

div.head: Cairo Flower Show.
div.p: As already announced, H.H. the Khedive will open the K.H.S. annual exhibition at Ghezireh to-morrow at 3 p.m. The show will be open to the public at 3.30 p.m., and on Sunday at 10 a.m.

div.head: The "Freres" Case.
div.p: Judgment in the "cause celebre" at Mazaltob and Mansour v. the Christian Brothers will be given next week. The case was heard before the Second Civil Chamber of the Cairo Mixed Courts on Wednesday in camera.

div.head: Port of Damietta.
div.p: The Egyptian Government has been unable to entertain the petition of the inhabitants of Damietta that steps should be taken to improve that port as so many other more urgent schemes are awaiting the consideration of the Government.

div.head: Terrible Accident
div.p: A terrible accident occurred last night at the Alexandria terminos of the Ramleh Electric Railway. While a native tram inspector was passing from one car in motion to another he missed his footing and fell under the wheels, his body being cut clean into pieces.

div.head: St. Andrew's Church.
div.p: A service of unusual interest will take place at St. Andrew's, Alexandria, on Sunday next, when six gentlemen will be ordained to the eldership of the church. Their names are Mosers, Clarkson, Chorlian, Dingle, Marr, Thomas, and Major Pringle.

div.head: Merchant Seamen's Home.
div.p: The post office at the Seamen's Home Alexandria, has been admitted to the postal and money order service. The innovation should prove a great boon to the thousands of British seamen who frequent the port. Last year, we believe, over £500 was remitted for the men through the medium of the manager, and it is expected there will be a large increase on this amount in the coming year.

div.head: A Novelty in Alexandria.
div.p: A project is on toot in Cairo to introduce a telephone newspaper, such as is in vogue in Buda-Pesth and has proved a great success, Meanwhile another European novelty is to be introduced at Alexandria in the shape of an Automatic Bar, which is to be opened with much ceremony by thore privileged to attend the inaugural ceremony to-morrow ovening. The bar is situated in Cherif Pache street.

div.head: Complaint against Omdeh.
div.p: The Italian Consulate at Cairo has received complaints regarding the conduct of one Mohamed Zalpat, omdeh of Taltieh. It appears that this functionary on Sunday last insulted a number of respectable Europeans who were sitting in a cafe known as the "Rendezvous des Chasseurs," by the Pyramids tram line. His drunkenness at the time explains but does not excuse such disgraceful conduct. We hope an example will be made of Mohamed Zalpat.

div.head: The New Banks.
div.p: The financial houses and the numerous international companies which have been founded lately, have persuaded a great many business men and employés of the necessity of knowing modern languages well. This explains the great increase in the number of inquiries at the Berlitz Schools (Cairo, 1, Sharia Kamel ; Alexandria, 12 Rus Rosette) for French, English, German, Italian, Arabic, etc. It is well known that the prices are within reach of everybody's purse and that the results are most rapid. [Advt.]

div.head: BANCO DI ROMA.
div.p: We learn that the capital of the Banco di Roma is to be increased at the end of the month from 80 to 40 million francs, and that the new issue will, like the former ones, be reserved to present shareholders.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive attended prayer at the Al Moayad Mosque to-day. To-morrow be will open the Flower Shwat Ghezireh at 3 p.m.

div.head: Anglo-American Nile Steamer & Hotel Company
div.p: River Transport of Goods Between Alexandria & Cairo

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Full Pension P.T. 50 a day. Visitors fron Cairo alight at Sidi-Gaber Station.

div.head: A SIGN OF THE TIMES.
div.p: "Al Ahram" publishes the following petition of a number of native women:

We, poor and weak women, request you to publish our complaints, as nobody not even the Government - has any pity for us. When any one of us has a difference with our husband over some question he leaves us and compels us to take proceedings against him in the Mehkemeh Sharieh for maintenance. Days and sometimes months may pass before the needy wife can get a judgment. When she does get it she goes to the Gouvernorat in triumph in the hope of obtaining the "nafaka" promptly after handing the document to the official ; but, alas, the Gouvernorat neglects the matter, and when the husband is finally summoned, many days after, he often pretends that be possesses nothing wherewith to support his poor wife and children. He neither offers the indispensable support nor divorces his wife, who will have, according to the law, to remain in suffering and misery. Now we hear that the Ministry of Justice is desirous of revising and amending the Mehkemeh regulations. Will the men of justice remember our grievances in making these improvements ? We pray the Ministry of Justice, the Ministry of the Interior, and the Mehkameh Sharieh to have pity on me, poor women ; we beg of them to save as from starvation, and to protect our honour.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES.
div.p: The creditors of the Sucreries et Raffineries d'Egypte met yesterday afternoon at the Mixed Courts. Cairo, under the presidency of Judge Tack. Prof. Sampaolo, acting syodio, was present,

Judge Tack opened the proceedings by informing the meeting that the definite appointment of a syndio was necessary. Maitre Carton de Wiart, in the name of the Sugar Corporation and the Hon. A. J. Davey, requested the Court to postpone the definite appointment of a syndio till Monday next, since two co syndio. had to be appointed and the creditors had not yet come to any decision as to who they should be. Jadge Tack replied that according to the Code the definite appointment of a syndio was necessary, afterwards co-syndios could be appointed if the importance of the case justified the measure.
It was finally decided to postpone the definite appointment of the syndio till to-morrow and to hold a meeting of creditors at 4 p.m. on Monday to appoint two co-syndios.

div.head: AMERICAN SQUADRON.
div.p: Some slight alteration has taken place in the future movements of the American squadron at present in Alexandria harbour. While the two cruisers, Galveston and Chattanooga, will proceed to China waters, the Tacoma will remain at the western end of the Mediterranean in order to render what assistance may be required by the drydock Dewey, before she enters the Suez Canal ,

Rear-Admiral Sigabee's flagship, the Brooklyn, will remain in port until after the visit to Cairo of the Prince and Princess of Wales, the Admiral and officers taking part in the festivities which will take place in their honour. These include, we believe, the trooping of the colours by the British garrison of Cairo.

After leaving Alexandria the Brooklyn will proceed direct to Philadelphia, where it is expected she will go out of commission. Although she is a comparatively new vessel, having been built in 1896, the cruiser is in many respects out of date, and she will be completely overhauled on her return to America.

The cruise of the squadron, which has lasted for some months, has been a great success. At every port the ships have called Admiral Bigsbee and his officers and men have been feted with the utmost cordiality. At Alex andria the officers have been attending a round of luncheons and dinners, and it will be something of a relief, we opine, when they go out to the open sea and resume their normal life.

Admiral Sigebee was particularly charmed with the reception he received at the hands of H.H. the Khedive, with whom he had a long and interesting conversation. As already announced, the Admiral and a number of the officers of the squadron will have the honour of dining with his Highness to morrow.

Yesterday afternoon Captain Nazro, of the Brooklyn, entertained a number of American ladies who are on the point of embarking for Europe, and in the evening Commander Smith gave a large dinner party on the Tacoma.

div.head: AUSTRO HUNGARIAN SQUADRON.
div.p: This morning, Baron Jacques de Menasce, President of Austro-Hungarian Benevolent Society; Mr. Emmanuel Stross, President of the Francois-Joseph Avile; Mr. Fenderl, Chairman of the Austro-Hongarian Chamber of Commerce; and Judge Koritzmios, President of the Mixed Court of Appeal, paid a visit to Rear-Admiral von Jedira and will lunch on board the Habsburg to-day.
This afternoon the leading members of the Austro-Hungarian colony will receive the Admiral and his officers at the Consulate.
On April 1 there will be a reception at the New Khedivial Hotel given by the colony, in honour of the visit of the squadron.
Op April 2 the seamen will be entertained to & splendid fete at the Alhambra Theatre.

div.head: ENGLAND AND TURKEY. THE AKABA QUESTION.PORTE REFUSES TO WITHDRAW TROOPS. PROBABLE NAVAL DEMONSTRATION.
div.p: The "Daily Telegraph '' says that according to a telegram from Constantinople, the Porte has addressed a note to the British Ambassador formally referring to withdraw the Turkish troops from Akaba and affirming that the territory is Turkisb, not Egyptian.
In diplomatic circles it is expected that England will make a naval demonstration, probably at Smyrna. It is denied that the territory is Turkish.

div.head: THE KING'S CUP. SHAMROCK III. TO RACE.
div.p: The "World" says that Shamrock III. is to compete for the King's Cup in August next, Sir Thos. Lipton is eligible owing to his membership of the New York Yacht Club.

div.head: WORLD'S RICHEST BABY.
div.p: A son has been born to Mr J. D. Rockefeller, jun.

div.head: THE BACHELORS' BALL
div.p: The Cairo bachelors may well congratulate themselves on their latest achievement, for everybody is still talking of the delights of their ball at the Ghezireh Casino on Tuesday night, and of the perfection of all the arrangements. The decorations were superb, the floor

was perfect, and the supper all that the heart of a man could desire The only complaint possible was with the weather, which was unaccountably cold for the season. and which it prevented the guests from enjoying to the

tall the beauties of the illuminated gardens. Fairyland could not have been more fairylike than those sylvan paths and stretches of award where coloured lights gleamed softly from among the trees and their reflections floated on the still bosom of the tiny lake. The Khedivial Band stationed outside added still further to the attractions.

Among the hosts were the following gentlemen :-Lord Edward Cecil, Sir Vincent Corbet, Col.' W. S. Sparkes, Major Palmer, Major Watson, Major Garner, Capt. Gordon, Capt. Grant, Capt. Stockwell, Capt. McMurdo, Capt. Betbell, Capt. F. J. Brakervridge, Mr. H. Greville, Mr. H. W. Haton, Mr. C. Higgins, Mr. J. P. Kershaw, Mr. J. W. Lombard, the Messrs. Reid, Mr. Carter Wilson Mr. E. H. Gordon, Mr C. Royle, Mr. J. W. Rassell, Mr. K. Speir. Me. P. O. Tribe, Mr. S. P. Watson, and Mr. A. L. Webb, and no more indefatigable or genial master of ceremonies could be found than Major J. K. Watson,
who more than ever that night was voted not most popular man in Cairo.

It would be impossible to enumerate all those who were enjoying the gentlemen's hospitality on that occasion. All the brightest the and fairest of Cairo's best were there, and the ball owed not a little of its success to

the fact that Lord and Lady Cromer were present with Lady Beatrice Thynne and their many other guests. There were of course many beautiful frocks to be seen, and a wonderful display of jewels. The Hon. Mrs. Findlay was wearing diamonds with a beautiful coptome of pale pink satin, and Larly Oppenheimer bad some wonderful pearls with a dress of black. The Hon. Miss Henneage was in a very pretty fresh frook of blue chiffon, and Mrs. Laidlaw looked extremely well in pale pink chiffon with trails of roses, Miss Leverich's dress of white chiflon was quite one of the prettiest to be seen, and Mrs. Maclean was in white satin.

div.head: HELIOPOLIS OASIS.
div.p: M. Empain is returning to Egypt at the end of this month in connection with the settlement of some outstanding questions with the Egyptian Government in regard to the Cairo Electric Railways and Heliopolis Oasis Company.
It is expected that the company will be launched some time next month.

div.head: THE SCHOOL SPORTS.
div.p: Favoured by capital weather, and held before a large attendance, the Government Schools Athletic Sports yesterday were a thorough success. Among those present on the Ghezireh ground were Lord and Lady Cromer, the Prime Minister, the Sirdar and Lady Wingate, Hossein Pacba Pokbry, Yacoub Paobs Artio, Baron de Villebois, Mme and Mlles de Villebois, Sir William Garstin, Mr. P. Macbell, Coles Pacha Mr. Webb, Mr. and Mrr. Elliott, Mr. and Mrs. Sharmen, Col. Matebett, Crook sbank Pacha, Dean and Mrs. Butober, Capt. Protheroe Smith, Mr. and Mrs. Mackenzie, Mr. Boyd-Carpenter, Mr. Wild, Mr. Amos and Miss Amos, Major and Mrs. Doffos, Dr. and Mrs. Phillips. The grandstand was quite full, and a crowd composed largely of friends and relations of the school-boys swarmed everywhere-but on the track.
The arrangements did credit to the committee and the stewards and every event commenced punctually, while no interval was unduly protracted.

The performances were all up to, and some well above, the average Ahmed Sbakir did very fair time for a school-boy in the 100 yards race for the pupils of the Secondary Schools, and followed op his success by getting the quarter-mile by about three and a ball yards. The hordles gave a good race but there was a certain want of style about the performance. None of the competitors seemed to have been trained to hurdle properly : had they understand how to fly their hurdles their time world have been greatly improved.

The big jump was divided between T, Mohamed Negati Abazs and Mob. Bi Sawi Mustapha, who succeeded in beating previous records at the school sports by 4 inches most creditable performance. The Towfikieh team was much too heavy for its opponents of the Khedivieh in the tug-of-war, and fairly pulled its opponents off their legs in double quick rims.

The gymnastics were really good. The teams had been well trained and did their work very thoroughly, especially on the parallel bars. Individually they were perhaps not quite as good as the best of the public school gymnastic representatives one goes at Aldershot every spring, but can any British public school at present torn on a team of gymnasts with so high an average of merit throagbout

The drill and clob-swinging display given by the boys of the Primary schools was undoubtedly the best, from a spectacular point of view, of the events of the afternoon. The boys went through their physical drill in the most perfect time, their marching was perhaps not quite final to their drill, but their club swinging was extraordinarily good, and their Egyptian instructors and Sergt. Brookway have much to be proud of.

The appearance of the boys was thoroughly refreshing : they were healthily built and well set up, and whatever the criticisms that are directed against the Ministry of Public Instruction by a section of the Press, the critics cannot deny that a good proportion of the younger generation of Egyptians of the better classes promises well physically. The corpus sanum after all is the basis of the mens sana.

div.head:
IBADY PACHA'S TRANSFER.
NEWS RECEIVED WITH REGRET
div.p: The announcement that H.E. the Governor Mustapha Proba Ihady is shortly to be transferred to Alexandria, has been received with much regret. The Governor is very popular and deservedly so. During his term of o here, he has done all in his power to improve the condition of the town, and it is felt the "Sporting Club," among other things due to his energy. Much still remains to be done before Port Said can be considered an able place of residence, but the inhabitants must be grateful for the assistance of, and work done by, Ibady Pacha. If his appointment to be Gouvernorat of Alexandria is confirmed he will leave here with the very best wish all for his future progress and prosperity the good wishes will be coupled with regret losing such an energetic official.
On Sunday night a fire broke out on 1 the S.S. Simla. Prompt assistance was coming and what might have proved a small fire was soon got under control. Very little damage was done.

div.head: MARRIAGE.
div.p: "PLEBY HARBON. - At All Saints' Church, in Cairo, on the 22nd March, by the Very Rev. Dean Butcher, Jonathan Kidd, son of the late William Appleby, of the Egyptian State Railways, to Florence Ellen, daughter of Georg William Harbron, of St. Alban's, Hertfordshire.

div.head:
SOUTH AFRICA.INDIANS FOR THE MINES. MOTION OF CENSURE ON LORD
MILNER REJECTED.

div.p: HOUSE OF COMMONS. --Mr. Winston Churchill said that the Government had not received any application from the Transvaal for the introduction of Indians in the mines. It would be impossible to state beforehand the manner of dealing with such an application.

The motion of censure on Lord Milner was rejected without a division. The amendment moved by Mr. Winston Churchill was then adopted by 355 to 185. Mr. Chamberlain characterised the motion as vindictive petty persecution of a great public servant. Mr. Winston Churchill replied that while the Government admitted the truth and moderation of the resolution, its adoption would aggravate existing animosities in South Africa.

It is understood that the Government would welcome an application for the importation of Indians into the Transvaal on the lines of the Guiana system, as being calculated to ease the present situation, which the Government regards with anxiety.
The minority included a dozen Liberals and Labourites.

The Liberal Press approves the vote, which condemns a serious violation of British traditions. The Conservative organs accuse the Government of cowardice in yielding to the malios of partisans and declare that Lord Milner's position has been immensely strengthened by the vote, which they describe as disastrous to the Empire.
The mining houses are seriously considering the importation of Indians, but it is feared that the climate would result in a heavy mortality, which would render the project impracticable.

div.head:
HOUSE OF COMMONS.
NEW RULES OF PROCEDURE.

div.p: HOUSE OF COMMONS. - The Committee of Procedure recommends the House to meet at three instead of two, to abolish the dinner hour, and to rise at 11.30 p.m. (Reuter)
Austria is elaborating a fresh proposal which is likely anyhow to relieve the deadlock if it does not lead to an agreement. (Reuter)
Herr von Radowitz is ill and is keeping his room. The Conference will meet only on Saturday.
The miners' strike is spreading. Work is at a complete standstill in the northern basin.
King Edward has expressed his great satisfaction with his stay here.

div.head: ANGLO-EGYPTIAN TRADING CO.
div.p: On Thursday last at the Central Criminal Court came the conclusion of the trial, which had lasted seven days, of Staurt Dixon, Stabb Ross, 28, and George Bertram Ross, 35, both described as merchants, who were indicted for conspiring to obtain money in connection with the Anglo-Egyptian Trading Company (Ltd.).

The jury found both the prisoners guilty, and, in passing sentence, the Recorder said it was deplorable to find man of their undoubted ability engaged in a fraud of this kind. Referring to Stuart Ross's evidence, his lordship said the Act which enabled a prisoner to be called as a witness on his own behalf, although sometimes valuable when an accused person was wholly innocent, was highly dangerous when he was not innocent. He sentenced Stuart Ross to eighton months' hard labour and George Ross to twelve months' hard labour.

div.head: COMMISSION MUNICIPALE
div.p: La Commission Municipale s'est tennię le 21 mars 1906 à 4 b. p.m. sous la présidence de M. le Dr. Schiess pacha.

Présents: MM. Ahmed pacba Yehia, Ahmed bey Eyoub, Abdel Kader bey Ghériani, J. Barbaza, Em. Benachi, Hussein bey Riez, L'Escoffier, P. Fenderl, E. W. P. Foster, Kamel bey, Teymour, Harry P. Kingham, Baron A. de]: Menasce, Mohamed bey Mahfouz, A. Padoa bey, Amb. A. Ralli, D. Rieti, 0. Rothacker, M. Salvago, Em. Stross, Dr. G.Valensin, G. Zərvu. dachi, membres ; W. P. Chataway, administrateur ; I. Sedky bey, secrétaire.
Le procès-verbal de la Commission Municipale du 27 décembre 1905 est approuvé.
Mention est faite de l'envoi à tous les membres des procès verbaux des séances de la Délégation des 16, 23, 30 janvier 1906, 13, 21, 1: 27 février 1906.
Communication est donnée des lettres ci après de 8.E. le Ministre de l'Intérieur :

1. d'une lettre du 28 janvier 1906 informant que prenant en considération les raisons exposées par la Commission, le Ministère ne voit pas d'inconvénient à ce que la Municipalité se mette d'accord avec la Compagnie de Ramleh en vue de l'exercice d'un droit de contrôle vis-à-vis de oette Compagnie.
2. une lettre du 17 février 1906 proposant un mode d'échange entre le Gouvernement et la Municipalité par certains terrains des quais et des constructions appartenant à l'Etat

L'Administrateur expose qu'on Comité spécial avait été désigné par la Délégation pour l'étude des propositions du Gouvernement et que cette étude a donné lien à certain-8 modifications, qui ont été proposées à l'Écart, sauf ratifié sation antérieure de la Commission.
3. Une lettre du 17 février 1906 informant i que le Ministère de la Guerre consent à ce que
le fort el Nahas soit consigné à la Manic palité pour être incorporé aux paros.'

4. Une lettre du 20 février 1906 informant que le Ministère des Finances ne peut rien modifier à sa première décision en ce qui concerne la cession à la ville de la gestion des biens libres, vu que la coutection d'une nouvelle liste de ces biens accompagnée des plans demandera un temps assez long.
5. Une lettre du 21 février 1906 informant que le ministère des Finances regrette de ne pouvoir augmenter la contribution de l'Etat dans les dépenses du service sanitaire.
6. Une lettre du 22 février 1906 approuvant le nouveau tarif des voitures publiques.
7. Deux lettres des 25 février et 3 mars 196 portant approbation du règlement sur la mallbinisation obligatoire des solipèdes et ajoutant à ce règlement une disposition con
cernant l'inoculation des bêtes saisies avant leur admission dans les écuries de la Société protectrice des animaux
8. Une lettre du 28 février 1906 approuvant la nouvelle disposition votée par la Commission et portant une modification au règlement sur le fonde commun d'assurance des animaux de boucherie.

9. Une lettre du 8 mars 1906 émettant un avis favorable à la cession à l'université musul. mane d'Alexandrie des terrains des échecs du Gabbari, sous certaines conditions, que cette université aurait à remplir.
Sur la proposition de la Délégation, la Com. mission approuve l'ouverture des crédits suivants à prélever sur le budget extraordinaire :
1. L. B. 775 pour la construction d'une capaldi action devant relier les prisons de Hadra à l'égout du Rond Point, dont L. E. 350 seront supportées par l'administration des prisons.
Cette dépense est subordonnée à l'avis te. vorable du comité des travaux publics en ce qui concerne les détails techniques du projet.
2. L. E. 370 pour le dallage du trottoir du quai à Silailey.
3. L. E. 115 pour la confection de plaques pour le raccordement des charrettes et biey. clettes.
4. L. E. 230 pour le bornage des terrains de quai.
5. L. E. 300 pour la construction d'un objet de nécessité rue Ebn Toulon.
6. L. E. 284 pour la commande de nouveaux tuyaux et autres articles nécessaires à la brigade des pompiers.

M. Escoffier fait remarquer à ce anjet que ces dépenses de renouvellement assez fréquentes sont nécessitées particulièrement par les grande incendies, tel que celui qui a eu lieu dernièrement. Il ne serait que juste dans ces conditions que les compagnies d'assurance attribuent à des dépenses, auxquelles elles sont intéressées.
La Commission aborde l'examen des formalités préparatoires à la vente des terrains des quais.
A cet effet, il avait été communiqué aux membres des états so comparé de plans indiquant les estimations données aux divers lots par le Conseil d'évaluation et leur superficie respective.
Un cahier des charges élaboré par le comité da content eox avait été également distribué.

D'autre part, des tableaux présentés en séance indiquent le lotissement préparé par le Comité des Travaux Publics pour ce qui concerne la zone avoisinant la gare de Ramleh, zone que la Commission municipale, en approuvant à une dernière séance le lotissement des quais, avait tenne en suspens pour certaines études de détail.

Un échange d'idé je a lion au sujet de cette question. Diverses propositions portant certaines modifications au mode de vente prévu au règlement voté en 1905 sont présents mais ne rallient pas un nombre suffisant de suffrages.
La proposition suivant de MM. Fonderl et Parlera Bay est adoptée par 18 voix :

"L'assemblée approuve les plans de lotissement de la zone avoisinant la gare de Ramleh ainsi que le cahier des charges, le catalogage et les estimations qui lui sont soumis et en décide la publication.

"Elle décide que la Délégation fixera successivement les mises en vente hebdoma sires selon le règlement en s'inspirant de la délibération du 13 décembre 1995, la première enchère devant avoir lieu dans les derniers jours d'avril 1906 et les ventes devant être suspensives entre juillet et octobre inclusivement.
" Elle approuve seynod tonante la partie da! pro dg-verbal relative à ce vote."

Communication est donnée d'une lettre du 16 janvier de S B. le Ministre de l'Intérieur annonçant une lettre du 10 janvier du Ministère des Travaux publics relative au projet de construction de nouveaux ponts sur le canal Mahmoudieh.;

D'après le rapport de la Commission chargée de l'étude des moyens de porter remède à l'insuffisance des voix de communication entre les deux rives la canal Mahmoudieh, il y aurait lieu de construire deux nouveaux nonts, dont l'an entre les ponts Ibrahim et Zulficar et l'autre à Karmous ainsi que d'é. élargir le pont Ibrahim.
Le coût approximatif de ces trois ponts serait de LE 18 510 pour lequel le Ministère demande si la Municipalité est disposée à ea supporter une partie.

La Commission, sur la proposition de M. Excoffier et vu le raisons d'utilité publique I qui se rattachent au projet, décide de contribuer à cette dépense à concurrence de tiers et délègue MM. Benachi et Ro: hacker, pour se mettre en rapport avec les autorités du gouvernement en vue de régler les détails et de traiter au besoin pour arriver à un accord dans l'intérêt d'une prompte solution de cette question.

Statuant sur une demande de la Société des tramways tendant an dédoublement de sa ligne à l'angle des rues Bab Akhdar et Bab Karasta, la Commission, vo l'avis de la Délé. gation, qui conclut à de qu'il y a lieu de ne permettre que le passage de trams d'une seule voiture en cet endroit autorise le dédoublement, sauf à l'administration à examiner à nouveau si les nécessités de la circulation publique rendent indispensable cette condition.
Elle approuve également la demande de la même compagnie tondant an dédoublement de la ligne de la rue Tewfik à côté de la Bourse, à la condition qu'un gardien soit posté à cet endroit.

Elle renvoie au comité du contentieux l'étude des propositions de la Délégation concernant de nouvelles amendes dues par des fournisseurs, étude å entreprendre ensemble avec d'autres questions de cette nature renvoyées au dit comité.

La Commission approuve les expropriations et destinations indiquées dans les procès verbaux de la Délégation de: 30 janvier et 21 février 1906, sauf celles pour lesquelles l'esti. mation a été laissées pong en raison d'une divergence de vie, 'les-ci devant atteindre pour être réglées quae décision soit prise en ob qui concerne la base sur laquelle les estimations doivent être faites. A ce sujet la Commission demande à MY. Rothacker, Menseco et Zervudachi d'étudier la question et de lai faire des proposing à une prochaine séance.
La Commission autorise de défendre dans plusieurs affaires judiciaires.
La séance est levée à 7h. et 1/2 p.m.

div.head: THE MAKING OF EGYPT.
div.p: Sir Auckland Colvin's new book, The Making of Modern Egypt," is the latest publication dealing with this country.

Sir Auckland Colvin dates the commencement of the history of "Modern Egypt" from the British occupation in 1882, and he tells the story of the twenty-two years which elapsed between that date and the Anglo-French Agreement in considerable detail and in an interesting manner. Space will only permit here a brief indication of his general conclusion, and this cannot be given better than in his own words :

"Looking backward over the past two and twenty years, Great Britain, after all her mistakes and mishaps, has much on which she may congratulate herself. She may congratulate herself on having escaped from the blunder of an early withdrawal of her forces from Egypt, which would have led to fresh international complications; and from the still greater blunder of escorting the Turk back to Cairo. She may congratulate herself on having put an end to the dire tyranny of the Dervish rule in the Egyptian Sudan, and on her share in the work of restoring in those regions a reign of justice and of peace She may congratulate herself on being established, with the connert of all Europe, in Egypt, where she strider, like a modern Colossus, across the narrow entrance which leads from the Western to the Eastern hemisphere, and keeps watch over the approaches to her Indian Empire. Above all, she may congratulate herself on having installed in Cairo, from the hour of her arrival, the one man who by natural aptitude, by experience, and by character, was needed to secure her interests, and to ensure the well-being of the people for whom she had assumed responsibility."
What," Sir Auckland Colvin asks, "has been the secret of Lord Cromer's success?" A mere extract from the answer to this question must suffice here:

"That he has shown extraordinary capacity for labour, great financial and economic skill, untiring patience, high moral courage, much insight into native character; that he has gained general confidence by habitually frank outspokenness and candour ; all this, though true, scarcely supplies a sufficient answer to the question. The solution is probably to be found on examining the line of policy which he has adopted. It has been in the non-controversial sense of the word, a distinctly liberal policy. Its aim has been the greatest good of the greatest number, general content based on general well being... He has habitually looked at all questions, not solely from the point of the educationalist, or the administrator, but as much as possible from the point of view of the Egyptian himself."
Justice at last is done to the late Khedive, upon a complete knowledge of the facts, by Sir Auckland Colvin -

"When he was called on to decide broad issues or to confront great difficulties, he saw his way rapidly to a right conclusion. He well maintained the dignity of his high position. for example, when, on the eve of the bombardment of Alexandria, he was invited to take refuge on the decks of a British man-of war. He replied to that proposal without hesitation, that 'if he sheltered himself on board a war vessel, whose guns were trained on the forte of his country, he could never again show his face in Egypt! So he retired, guarded only by matinou-soldiers, to Ramleh, in the neighbourhood of Alexandria, whence few of those who bade him farewell expected that he would be permitted to return."

As regards the earlier life of the Khedive, before the British occupation, another passage is worth quotation :**"There was in Tewfik Pacha a reserve of reasonableness and sound judgment, and an honourable belief in the good faith of advisers whom he trusted, which are no mean substitute for experience directly acquired by lons handling of public affairs. He had confidence in the English, and he especially felt the value of their support in the presence of French ambition. But as he had no wish to be swallowed up by army power he aimed at being friendly with all."

As regards the fitness of General Gordon for the tark of withdrawing the garrisons from the Sudan, Sir Auckland remarks :"With all his splendid qualities, General Gordon was the most unfit selection conceivable for a mission of which retreat wa to he the leading feature, and in the course of which the sacrifice of some of those who had remained loyal to him and to Egypt might prove inevitable. To send him not to achieve fresh success but to withdraw from the scenes of former triumphs, and possibly to turn his back on friends who in humbler spheres had shared them, was to impose on him a task for which by character, as by past achievement; be was eminently and absolutely, unfitted."

It has always been a debatable question whether Mr. Gladstone's Government were right in refusing to be carried away by the national l'amour for revenge of Gordon and immediate reconquest of the Sudan. The Government had always and in all circumstances declared their intention to evacuate the Sudan, and in this decision Sir Auckland Colvin seems to think they were right:

"Troubles were thickening on our Indian frontier, and it seemed very possible that towards the clone of 1885 we should be drawn into a war with Russia. British troops could not be spared ; Egyptian troops unaided were not equal to the task. Egypt herself was in a condition little removed from bankruptcy, and could not devote a piastre to military operations. Her need of rest and recuperation was urgent. In the face of much opposition, and in spite of violent attacks, the Government decided that Egypt should evacuate, though not necessarily abandon, the Sudan. Subsequent events have proved the wisdom of a decision which was received at the time with very considerable disfavour."
Sir Auckland draws an amusing contrast between the dispositions of the French and English officials in Egypt:

"Keen of wit, incisive of tongue, choleric of disposition, sensitive as children, kindly as women, the Frenchman was the very opposite of the phlegmatic, imperturbable Briton, whom he lagged along with him in his heated course."

There are a great many people even in Egypt who regard the reconquest of the Sudan by Lord Kitchener as at least one brilliant achievement for which the British War Office may take some credit. Sir Auckland Colvin completely banishes this vain belief :

"No precantion had been neglected, nothing had been overlooked, as little as might be bad been left to the risks of warfare. There had been no 'unfortunate incidents.' The London War Office could neither claim credit nor suffer discredit from the result. The operation had been entirely in the band of the Anglo-Egyptian authorities, unhampered by control from Pall Mall."
Not the least interesting portion of Sir Auckland Colvin's work in the debited to the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan :

"Our country's enterprise among the tribes of the Sudan is, in the secular sense, & purely missionary endeavour ; the sceptic might add, a Quixotic adventure I may be that the great expenditure may here fner bring good results; that the rivers of Central Africa may turn the sands of her deserts into sugar plantations, or cotton fields, or stretches of endless wheat. Mineral wealth may award the explorer and the State ; increasing traffic may add to the public revenues. But all this by universal consent lies in the far future."

Of the progress of Cairo he says, "The constant flitting to and fro of tramcars with their brilliancy of innumerable electric spark ets in the clear Egyptian nights, contrasts strangely with memories still recent of those long shadow file of noiseless camels on the sandy Ezbekieh, which have passed on their way, and are now as much lost to us in the mists of time as the caravan that brought Joseph to Egypt."

div.head: KAISER AS PATRON OF ISLAM.
div.p: In a speech delivered in the German Reichstag last week, Herr Bebel, the leader of the Social Democrats, said that the Emperor aspired to be regarded as the patron of the Mohammedan religion and the guardian of Moslems throughout the world. The Emperor's journey to Constantinople, Jerusalem, and Morocco were undertaken to produce this impression among Moslems.

The whole Mohamedan world, declared Herr Bebel, believed that the Emperor bore the banner of Islam. The Clerical Deputy Herr Bisberger, confirming Herr Bebel's assertions, declared that Mohamedanism was the official State religion in German East Africa, where the natives regarded the Emperor as the supreme chief of Islam.

div.head: EGYPT AND BURTON.
div.p: There is a very interesting passage bearing on Egypt in Mr. Thomaw Wright's new life of Sir Richard Burton, and in the following anecdote, Mr. Wright tells us that indirectly the present state of Egypt is owing to Burton :

On Oct. 28 ( 88 ) the Bortons went down to HarfieId, where there was a large party, but Lord Salisbury devoted himself chiefly to Burton. After they had discussed the Eastern Question, Lord Salisbury said to Burton, "Now go to your room where you will be quiet, and draw up a complete programme for Egypt."
Burton retired, but in two or three minutes returned with a paper which he handed to Lord Salisbury.
"You've soon done it," said his lordship and on folding the paper he found the single word "annex."
"If I were to write for a month," commented Burton, on noticing Lord Salisbury's disappointment, "I could not say more."

However, being further pressed, he elaborated his very simple programme. The policy he advocated was a wise and humane one. and had it been instantly adopted, untold trouble for us, and much oppression of the miserable natives, would have been avoided. Since then we have practically followed his recommendations, and the present prosperous state of Egypt is the result.
Large Park, Tennis, Sport Ground. Situated on the lake, opposite Mont Blanc.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Captain Mannton E. T. Gunthorpe, Alexandra, Princess of Wales's Own Yorkshire Regiment, has been selected for service with the Khedive's Army, and joins at Cairo. Captain Gunthorpe got his first commission in the "Green Howards" in December, 1896, his company in June, 1904. and he was with the 1st Battalion in the most of its fighting and trekking in South Africa. In the first part of he war he was attached to the 2nd Battalion Royal Irish Rifles, including the operations at Stormberg, and subsequently he joined the "Green Howards" at De Aar, and was with them in the advance towards Kimberley, he action of Paardeberg, where he was slightly wounded ; actions of Vet River, Zand River, Johannesburg, Pretoria, Diamond Hill, the operations oust and west of Pretoria ; and the operations in Cape Colony and the Transvaal generally down to the close of the war. In the last year of the campaign he was adjutant and transport officer to the battalion (Queen's medal with five claspe, King's medal with two clasps, mentioned in despatches).

Captain E. W. S. Mahon, Royal Engineers, who from duty at Pembroke Dock has been specially attached to the Egyptian Army for survey duty, had considerable experience with the China Field Force during the Boxer campaign of 1900,when he was employed as a special service officer. It is just twelve years since he got his first commission in the gallant sappers.

On the 24 h. inst the battleship Illustrious will be commissioned at Chatham by Captain R. H. Johnson Stewart, with a nucleus crew preparatory to service with the Channel Fleet, in which she relieves the battleship Albion. The Illustrious was last employed on the Mediterranean Station and since her return from there the sum of £70,000 was spent in refitting her. It may be remembered that Capt in Johnson Stewart was in command of the Naisd, erg ged in the blockade of the Somali coast in the operation against the Mad Mullah, when his brother, Captain Johnson Stewart, was killed in action.

The battleship Queen, which made such good shooting last year, has been ordered home from the Mediterranean next month, and will be re-commissioned at Devonport for another term of service in the same waters.
It has been notified that the position of the wagons of the 15-ponder batteries R.F.A., in action, will be on the left of the gun.

div.head: NERVES WRECKED.

p.hi: Health undermined by hard work and
anxiety, this lady collapsed; bloodless, exhausted, unable to sleep or eat, she was in despair. Then a

div.p: Mrs. S.E. DAWBER who is the energetic owner of a prosperous fruiterer's business at 8. New square, Wigan, is a typical woman of business. But her responsibilities were the cause of a trying crisis, from which only Dr Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People succeeded in reasoning her. "About four years ago said Mrs. Dawber, "long hours of hard work and constant attention to business so undermined my health that without warning I collapsed, and became a nervous wreck, unable to do anything.

"I was in a very low state of health, and consulted a medical man, who pronounced my trouble to be general debility and nervous collapse. My face was deathly pale, and I was in a most distressingly bloodless state, exhausted by any exertion. Anemia developed and I lost appetite entirely. All food was bitter to my ralate; even milk caused indigestion. Life was unbearable ; I could not rest night or day. Nothing seemed to afford me any relief, and I was in despair.

One day I became interested in a book about cares efforted by Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People I, bought a box and after taking a few pills, that I was feeling better. My appetite returned: I felt blood tingling in my veins, and I was not easily fatigued.

div.head: CHRONIQUE THEATRALE
div.p: Cetopéra, qui avait été délaissé si longtemps après une "première" désastreuse, obtient partout aujourd'hui, 13 ans après la mort du compositeur, le succès et la vogue qu'il mé. ritait. Catalani est certainement le compositeur le plus original et le plus personnel de l'école moderne italienne. Il a horreur de la banalités Bien qu'en pen uniforme, il se distingue néanmoins par une finesse, une élégance et an idéal exquis.
L'interprétation de l'æavre a été admirable. Mme Ross, Zepilli et Ponzano, ainsi que MM. Palet et Amato se sont fort distingués chacun dans leur rôle respectif.

Une bonne part du succès de la soirée est due à l'orchestre qui a exécuté d'une façon magistrale cette partition si difficile. Nos félicitations à l'habile Maestro Zuocani, qui a sa transformer la phalange qu'il a Bons ses ordres on an des meilleurs orchestres de l'Europe.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie) La baisse, déterminée par les réalisations, la faillite des Sucreries et la situation politique, s'accentue aujourd'hui.
La National Bank tombe à 28 1/16, l'Agricole à 9 15/16, la Cassa à 215, l'Urbaine à 6 1/8, la Crown Brewery à 280, l'Alexandria Water à 14 11/16, etc.
En revanche, le Comptoir atteint 7 3/16 l'action et 46 la part de fondateur, la Daïra 18 1/2 et l'Investment 1 11/38 acbeteure.
La Land Allotment continue à être délaissée à 4 l'action et à 165 la part de fondateur.

Ce sont les petites valeurs qui ont été le plus échangées durant la matinée, en particulier l'Investment et le Trast. La Cassa, depuis qu'elle est manipulée par certains spéculateurs, a des soubresauts fantastiques souvent en quelques heures de 215 à 230 et de 280 & 215.

Le calme qui commence à gagner les valeurs dont s'est emparée naguère la spéculation pour les porter à des cours que l'état de ces sociétés ne justifie pas suffisamment, est an bon présage pour les valeurs anciennes et solides délaissées jusqu'ici à des cours avantageux.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: A Londres, le Consolidé anglais et l'Unifie Sont restés bien invariés à 90 5/8 et 106. LA National Bank est renseignée en baisse de ¼ 28 8/8 et la Daïra de 1/8 & 181/4. L'Agricole s'est maintenue à 10.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Égyptien a regagné 4 trados á 800. La Banque d'Athènes a réactionné de 1 frado à 151.
Notre marché des valeurs a présenté ce matin les mêmes caractéristiques qu'hier : calme, très peu d'affaires et, conséquence naturelle, léger tassement des cours sur quelques valeurs.

La National Bank a perda 1/16 à 28 1/16 ; l'action poubelle a fléchi à 27 3/16. L'Agricole s'est maintende à 10. La Cassa di Sconto est remontée à 221 l'action ancienne et 821 la nouvelle. Le Comptoir Financier s'est inscrit a 7.
L'action Crédit Foncier est restée immobile 798. La Daira, plas animée, a avancé 18 7/16-1/2.

L'Immobilière est revenue à 390 ; la part de fondateur à 630. L'action Land Allotment s'est traitée entre 3 7/8 et 15/16; la part de fondateur est remontée de 145 à 160. L'action Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux a été cotée à 4 1/8; la part de fondateur à 15.

La part de fondateur Brasserie des Pyramides a atteint 80 pour clôturer à 88. On a fait courir le bruit que la Société a vendu ses terrains de Gizeh ; l'information n'est pas exacte, mais elle pourrait bien ne pas tarder à le devenir. Les Ciments ont fléchi à 86; la part de dividende à 32. Les Sucreries sont remontées à 12 - 13.
Les Omnibus ont atteint 32 1/2—83. En outre il y a en une forte demande en Automobiles à £ 8 1/4.
Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Nongovich ont faibli à 17 1/8. Les Upper Egypt sont restés à 5 7/16.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land, en bonne tendance, se sont inscrits à 8 1/2. Les Estates ont été traités entre 1 15/16 et 2. Les New Egyptian ont clôturé à 35 sh. 6; les Hooker entre 11/16 et 1/8 ; les Markets à 24 ab. ; les Walker and Me marachi à 0 13/16.

Relativement à la oréation de £ 2,000,000 d'obligations nouvelles 3 1/2 pour cent de l'Agricultural Bank of Egypt, dont nous avons parlé avant hier, on ajoute que plus de la moitié de la somme (an million et quart) est déjà placée en avances faites aux cultivateurs indi

On s'attend à un mouvement sur l'Anglo American Line. Les achats qui se pratiquent discrètement depuis quelques jours doivent, assurément, être attribués au fait que la Société est sur le point de conclure la vente de ses tarrains de Boulic aux conditions les plus brillantes.

Oa annonce d'Alexandrie que le conseil d'administration de la Société des Tramways a décidé de mettre prochainement en circulation un certain nombre d'omnibus automobiles dans les principales rues de la ville. Ces automobiles contingent et relieront les lignes de tramways.

C'est à cette décision que serait dû le mouvement de hausse qui s'est produit récemment sur les Privilégiées et les Dividendes. Ou soppe que ce nouveau service est appelé à augmenter considérablement les recettes de la Compagnie.

A l'assemblée générale ordinaire de la Société des Immeubles d'Egypte, tenue à Alexandrie le 19 da courant, il a été décidé de distribuer, pour l'exercice 1905, P.E. 186 1/2 par action ordinaire et PE 39 par action de jouissance, payables à partir du 9 avril prochain à la National Bank of Egypt.
Très forte hausse sur les cotons en Amérique. Hier le disponible a gagné non moins de 40 points, le Mai 86 et l'Octobre 23.
Les arrivages ont été do 18,000 balles contre 29,000.
Le marché de Liverpool est ferme.
loi, le Mai, qui avait fini hier soir à 20 17/32, a ouvert ce matin à 20 5/8 pour clôturer à 20 17/32.

div.head: Vade Mecum for the Homeward Bound
Picture Post Cards
div.p: "The Egyptian Gazette" Series is the most artistic collection to be found in Egypt.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: TAORMINA Hotel Metropole.
div.p: First-Class House. Beautiful Position. German Management.
Same Proprietor Hotel Grande Bretagne, Catania.

div.head: Grand Hotel San Domenico
div.p: First Class English Family Hotel with Garden, Terraces, Lawn Tennis, Winter Garden, 25 beds, Heating, Ancient historical convent, sitautated in the finests and most select part of Taormine. Views of Etna and the Ionian Sea. French Cooking. Most comfortable Pension. House warmed.

div.head: SORRENTO Hotel Tramontano
div.p: Hotels Tramontano & Tasso, & Hotel Pension Syrene.

These excellent Hotels, which are situated in the best part of what is worthily named the "Beauty Spot of Italy," are the annual resort of the most distinguished English and American families. The principal centre for excursions. Electric light throughout. Tennis. English church.

div.p: The most recently built Hotel in Salsomaggiore, and on which no expense has been spared to render it completely up-to-date as regards hygiene and comfort. The Hotel is directly connected with the New Bathing Establishment by a covered passage.
For prospectus and particulars apply to the Manager.

div.head: Engleberg (1,019 Metres above Sea), Switzerland.
div.p: Mr. Alfred Hug, Proprietor and Manager

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: LAKE OF LUCERNE. Grand Hotel, Axen-Fels.
div.p: Best Spring resort. 2,200 ft. above the sea. Every comfort.

The leading Hotel for English and American families. Trains every fifteen minutes by Electric Railway from Brunnen to Axen-Fels. The Park having a frontage of nearly a mile on the lake, is one of the prettiest in Switzerland.

div.head: THE GRAND HOTEL LIDO.
div.p: Hotel with its dependencies (Swiss Hotel), in the most delightful situation of the Lido at the landing place, five minutes walk from the bathing place. Wonderful view of the Legune of Venice. Room from 3 lire, with board from 8.50 per day. No mosquitos. Very dry and safe air.
Address- SOCIETE BACHI, LIDO, VENICE, ITALY.
